awd_titl_txt: Evolving Minds in Early Elementary School: Foundations for a Learning Sequence on Natural Selection Using Stories
awd_abstract_narration:
The ECR (Education and Human Resources Core Research) program emphasizes fundamental STEM education research that will generate foundational knowledge in the field. Research shows that world-wide, despite its importance to the life sciences, natural selection remains one of the most widely misunderstood processes in biology. Specifically, studies reveal that scientific misconceptions about natural selection not only persist among high school students and undergraduates who are usual targets of instruction on evolution by natural selection, but, disturbingly, also among many of the teachers trained to teach them. Research further reveals that the origin of many of these misconceptions can be traced to intuitive cognitive biases found at the elementary school level. This project will address this problem by building and testing a learning sequence on natural selection at the early elementary grades before intuitive theoretical misconceptions are likely to have become entrenched. This effort will expand existing infrastructure for research and education currently supported through a university, to school partnership involving elementary educators, curriculum developers, professional development providers, interdisciplinary academic researchers and cognitive development expert consultants.  

The project focuses on understanding whether the proposed natural selection learning sequence is even viable and beneficial for elementary school students and teachers given children's representational constraints, the development and entrenchment of intuitive cognitive biases and teacher science anxiety. The two central aims will be to: (1) develop the core architecture and explore the feasibility of an expanded elementary school learning sequence on natural selection; (2) examine the educative professional development benefits to elementary school teachers of the developed story-based intervention materials. Six interventions will be conducted through an iteratively designed series of laboratory, afterschool, or classroom empirical studies to explore the viability of mechanistically teaching K-2 children about within- and between-species adaptation by natural selection. Due to the non-binary nature of data that will be generated by the studies, core analyses will be repeated measures ordinal logistic regressions with chi-squared tests for significance. Effect sizes will be indexed by odds ratio. Results from this work will advance scientific knowledge and educational practice by yielding insights about children?s capacities as explanatory thinkers and theory-builders. Materials and products (storybooks, animations and assessment tools) will directly benefit schools, teachers, children and parents in the State of Massachusetts and nationally.

por.por_cntn:
Natural selection is a fundamental mechanism of evolution, the unifying principle of biology. As a cornerstone concept within the life sciences, it is a focus of science education throughout the world. However, decades of research have shown that, even after instruction, natural selection is one of the most widely misunderstood processes. Child developmental research suggests that the origin of many such misconceptions can be traced to naturally developing untaught or “intuitive” cognitive biases found in early elementary school children. And yet, prevailing assumptions about young children’s cognitive limitations mean that comprehensive and causally coherent instruction on the mechanism of natural selection is typically delayed until 12- to 17-years of age, long after intuitive theoretical misunderstandings are likely to have become entrenched.

 

Our NSF-supported project offered an innovative response to this educational challenge. Building on earlier NSF-funded studies that demonstrated young children’s capacities to productively learn the counterintuitive logic of adaptation by natural selection (i.e. evolution of specialized body parts) from a custom picture storybook intervention, we sought to develop, and explore the benefits of, an expanded storybook-based teaching sequence to promote elementary-school children’s insight into even larger scale macro-evolutionary concepts, specifically, common descent and the evolution of novel species. In focusing on young children’s construction of mechanistic explanations, our project therefore adopted an approach that is largely absent from typical elementary school science curricula which often focus on learning of piecemeal facts rather than broadly applicable mechanisms. Our project also sought to explore whether non-science-specialist elementary school teachers would benefit from our custom storybook intervention materials by, for example, building their own scientific content knowledge and confidence.

 

Our research resulted in several major findings. For example, we confirmed that, from early elementary school, children often display intuitive biases and preconceptions that act as barriers rather than bridges to learning counterintuitive scientific concepts like natural selection and common ancestry. Despite this, we also confirmed that 7- to 10-year-old children’s capacities for learning complex counterintuitive scientific ideas have been underestimated. Children are able to overcome their mistaken preconceptions to successfully acquire and apply an accurate understanding of small and large-scale natural selection after engaging with coherently structured custom storybook-based educational interventions. They also benefit from these learning materials whether the sequence of storybooks is read aloud to them --individually or in classroom settings-- or whether they view animated versions of the storybooks on a screen. Importantly, our findings also contested traditional views of cognitive development that assume that learning involves the restructuring and replacement of old theoretical ideas with newer ones. Instead, we found support for an alternative position which argues that learning involves the layering of newer ideas over older intuitions such that the older ideas persist and co-exist, reasserting themselves over time even in highly successful learners. These results therefore point to the need for early science curricula that are coherently structured to progressively revisit foundational scientific ideas over multiple grades with a view to building robust depth of understanding. This approach contrasts with contemporary elementary science approaches that instead emphasize building breadth of knowledge and thus involve small shallow islands of instruction on different scientific ideas in each grade.

 

Finally, our research found that our storybook intervention materials benefit parents who attempt to teach natural selection to their children even if those parents already have a solid understanding of evolutionary mechanisms themselves. They also benefit elementary school teachers, promoting both their scientific knowledge base and feelings of confidence. Preliminary findings suggest that professional development materials for teachers are especially helpful if they incorporate information about children’s and adults’ cognitive development and intuitive preconceptions about evolution. Other outcomes from this project include the crowdfunded dissemination of hundreds of free copies of the storybook How the Piloses Evolved Skinny Noses to elementary schools and teachers throughout the United States and the preparation for trade publication of two further evolution storybooks. The evidence yielded by this NSF project has led to the design of a fuller evidence-based inquiry curriculum on evolution for elementary school. The benefits of the Evolving Minds curriculum are currently being assessed with NSF support.
